user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 options)
{
    int32                              final_status;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    final_status = OS_SUCCESS;
    impl         = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    /*
    ** create the underlying mutex
    */
    status = pthread_mutex_init(&impl->mut, NULL);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar mutex could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
        ** create the condvar
        */
        status = pthread_cond_init(&impl->cv, NULL);
        if (status != 0)
        {
            pthread_mutex_destroy(&impl->mut);

            OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
            final_status = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }

    return final_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarCreate_Impl:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:

- pthread types and functions (pthread_mutex_t, pthread_cond_t, pthread_mutex_init, pthread_cond_init) are POSIX library APIs, not C language extensions.
- The static inline functions are standard C (C99 and later) and do not use compiler-specific extensions.
- The typedefs int32_t/uint32_t are from <stdint.h> (standard C), and the custom aliases int32/uint32 are ordinary typedefs.
- The macros shown (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_DEBUG) use standard preprocessor features; the variadic macro syntax (OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__)) is standard since C99, not a compiler extension.
- Pointer operations, address-of usage in the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro, and the other language constructs in the function are all standard C constructs.

There are no occurrences of known compiler-specific extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, __builtin_... functions, anonymous structs/unions as compiler-only extensions, or other documented compiler extensions. Therefore there are no fragments to flag for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 in this code.
